questions.question:
Question 1: A 6-month-old infant was brought to the OPD by his mother with a history of passing watery 
stools more than 4 times in the past day. On examination, the baby is alert and on pinching 
his skin, it goes back quickly. The infant weighs 5.7 Kg. What is the initial fluid of choice for 
treating diarrhoea in this infant?
questions.explanation:
In an infant with diarrhoea, the initial fluid of choice is oral rehydration solution (ORS). The glucose-dependent sodium and water absorption is the principle behind replacing glucose and 
sodium in a 1:1 molar ratio in the WHO oral rehydration solution (ORS). The low osmolarity of the 
ORS in the lumen as compared to the blood facilitate absorption of fluid and hence the 
electrolytes due to the solvent drag. Studies have shown that low osmolarity ORS causes reduction of stool output, decrease in 
vomiting and decrease in the use of unscheduled intravenous fluids without increasing the risk of 
hyponatremia. Other home available fluids that can be used are salted rice water/salted yoghurt 
drinks, vegetable/chicken soup with salt. ReSoMal is given to severely malnourished children. In this case, since the infant’s weight is 
appropriate for its age ORS is given.

questions.question: Question 2: The amount of total body water(TBW) in a term neonate weighing 3 Kg is approximately
questions.explanation:
The amount of total body water (TBW) in a term neonate is approximately 75% of the birth 
weight. So, in this case, 75% of 3kg is 2.25 litres. Note - TBW is 90% in early fetal life and becomes 60% by the end of the first year and stays the 
same till puberty.

questions.explanation:
The above image shows intraosseous cannulation for fluid transfusion in the anterior proximal 
tibia. The intraosseous route is an alternative to the intravenous (IV) route in the transfusion of fluids in 
shock. • The marrow of long bones has a rich network of vessels that drain into a central venous canal, 
emissary veins, and ultimately the central circulation. • So, the bone marrow functions as a non-collapsible venous access route. Intraosseous cannulation is recommended for patients in whom IV access proves difficult or 
unattainable. (e.g., in cardiopulmonary arrest). In such a case, if venous access is not available 173 
Sold by @itachibot within 1 min, an intraosseous needle should be placed in the anterior proximal tibia. Insertion sites for intraosseous infusion: • In the proximal tibia, 1-2 cm anteromedial from the tibial tuberosity • Distal tibia at the junction of the medial malleolus and the shaft of the tibia • Distal one-third of the femur

questions.question:
Question 4: A 9-year-old boy who has been operated on for craniopharyngioma presents with polyuria 
and polydipsia. On investigation, the serum osmolality is 305 mOsm/kg and urine osmolality 
is 250 mOsm/kg. The atrial natriuretic peptide (ANP) level is normal. What could be the 
cause?

options.b: Syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone secretion

questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario with serum osmolality and urinary osmolality, after a cranial 
surgery, suggests a diagnosis of post-surgical central diabetes insipidus (DI). Irreversible central 
DI follows most cases of complete resections of craniopharyngioma. Serum osmolality of >295 mOsm/L (normal: 280-295 mOsm/L) and the urine osmolality 
of <300 mOsm/L (normal: 500-850mOsm/L) are suggestive of DI. A water deprivation test is 
done to further classify the types of DI. Option A: In postoperative patients, because of IV fluids there is an acute expansion of ECF 
volume. This suppresses high ADH activity and causes diuresis with normal serum osmolality. Option B: In SIADH, serum osmolality is decreased. Option D: In cerebral salt-wasting syndrome there is hypersecretion ANP and their levels 
are usually elevated.

questions.question:
Question 5: All the following statements are true regarding zinc supplementation in children with 
diarrhoea except:

options.a: It leads to reduced duration, severity, and recurrence of diarrhea
options.b: It reduces the inappropriate use of antimicrobials
options.c: Excessive zinc can cause copper deficiency syndrome
options.d: It is given at a dose of 20 mg/day for 4 weeks

questions.explanation:
Zinc supplementation is usually given for a duration of 10 to 14 days. • Age <6 months: 10 mg/day • Age >6 months: 20 mg/day Zinc administration for diarrhoea management can significantly reduce mortality and hospital 
admission. In addition, it improves diarrhoea recovery rates and reduces the inappropriate use of 
antimicrobials. Excessive zinc therapy can lead to copper deficiency syndrome, hence requires the regular 
monitoring of plasma zinc and copper concentrations.

questions.question:
Question 6: A 5-year-old child brought to the hospital with a history of loose stools. The mother says he is 
irritable and drinks water hastily when given. On examination, eyes are sunken and during 
the skin pinch test, the skin retracted within two seconds but not immediately. What is the 
treatment for the child?

options.a: Administer the first dose of IV antibiotic and immediately refer to a higher center
options.b: Give oral fluids and ask the mother to continue the same and visit again the next day
options.c: Give zinc supplementation and oral rehydration solution only and ask mother to come back if
options.d: Consider severe dehydration, start intravenous (IV) fluids, IV antibiotics, and refer to a higher

questions.explanation:
The child in this scenario has some degree of dehydration, since the child is restless and irritable, 
drinks water readily, has sunken eyes, and the skin goes back slowly on the skin pinch test (<2 
seconds) with sunken eyes. 174 
Sold by @itachibot Treatment includes oral rehydration therapy and zinc supplementation according to WHO 
Integrated Management of Neonatal and Childhood Diseases (IMNCI) Protocol, Plan B. WHO IMNCI PLANS:

questions.question:
Question 7: Which of the following is not true about reduced(low)-osmolarity oral rehydration solution 
(ORS)?

options.a: It contains 20 mmol of potassium per litre
options.d: Citrate is provided to prevent or correct base deficit acidosis

questions.explanation:
The total osmolarity of low-osmolarity oral rehydration solution (ORS) is 245 mmol/L, and it is 
the most commonly used ORS. • Potassium is provided to replace the large potassium losses, thus preventing serious 
hypokalemia. • Citrate corrects base-deficit acidosis. • Glucose promotes the absorption of sodium and water in the small intestine. 175 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 8: The amount of sodium present in ReSoMal is
questions.explanation:
Rehydration solution for malnourished (ReSoMal) contains 45 mmol/L of sodium. Severely malnourished children have excess intracellular sodium (leaky cell membranes and 
reduced activity of the sodium–potassium pump). So, sodium intake should be reduced and a 
low-sodium oral rehydration solution (ReSoMal) is advised. Because severely malnourished 
children are deficient in potassium, ReSoMal contains extra potassium, as well as extra glucose or 
sucrose and selected minerals (Mg, Cu, Zn).

questions.question:
Question 9: 169 
Sold by @itachibot A 2-year-old child weighing 7 Kg, presents to the emergency with a history of vomiting and 
diarrhea for the last 3 days. On examination, the skin pinch over the anterior abdominal wall 
goes quickly to its original position. What is the interpretation of the skin pinch test in this 
child?

options.d: Skin pinch cannot be evaluated in this child

questions.explanation:
In the given scenario, the child is malnourished, so the skin pinch cannot be evaluated. The child is of age 2 years, and the expected weight is 12 Kg. But, the weight of the child here is 7 
Kg, which suggests that the child is malnourished. The child may be having edematous 
malnutrition (kwashiorkor), where skin may go back to the original position even in the presence 
of dehydration. Hence, the skin pinch is not reliable for the assessment of dehydration in this 
child. Reliable indicators of dehydration in the malnourished child include • Eagerness to drink • Cool and moist extremities • Weak radial pulse • Reduced urine flow

questions.question: Question 10: Which of the following is the most dangerous type of dehydration?
questions.explanation:
Hypernatremic dehydration is the most dangerous type of dehydration. Hypernatremia causes movement of water from brain cells into hypertonic extracellular fluid, 
causing brain cell shrinkage and shearing of blood vessels within brain. This leads to central 
nervous system hemorrhages and thrombosis. The fluid deficit is corrected slowly as rapid treatment of hypernatremic dehydration causes 
movement of water from the extracellular space into brain cells, leading to cerebral edema, 
seizures, brain herniation, and even death.

Question 11: What is the maximum concentration of dextrose that can be given through a peripheral 
vascular line in a neonate?
questions.explanation:
Through a peripheral vascular line, a maximum of 12.5% dextrose can be infused. 176 
Sold by @itachibot The dextrose concentration greater than 12.5% has an acidic pH and can cause irritation to the 
peripheral veins, which can lead to thrombophlebitis. Note: Central vein lines can be used for 25% D if needed.

Question 12: A 7-year-old boy weighing 30 Kgs has been posted for surgical resection of a tumor. What is 
the daily maintenance fluid required for this child while he’s NPO?
questions.explanation:
The daily maintenance fluid required for a child weighing 30 Kg is 1700 ml. Bodyweight method for calculating the daily maintenance fluid volume (also known as 
Holliday-Segar method) is used. Calculation: In the question, the weight of the child is given as 30 Kgs. So, the formula for >20 Kg is used. 1500 mL + (20 mL x weight more than 20 Kgs) Since the child weight is 30 Kgs, he/she is 10 Kgs more. Therefore, fluid required is = 1500 mL + (20 mL x 10) = 1500 mL + 200 mL = 1700 mL. Bodywei

questions.question: Question 13: Which of the following is the most common type of shock in children?
questions.explanation:
Hypovolemic shock is the most common type of shock in children. Cardiogenic shock: cardiac pump failure due to cardiomyopathies, myocarditis or congenital heart 
diseases. Hypovolemic shock: loss of body fluid due to diarrhea, vomiting or hemorrhage. Obstructive shock: mechanical barrier which obstructs the cardiac outflow like pericardial 
tamponade, tension pneumothorax, pulmonary embolism. 177 
Sold by @itachibot Septic shock: It is the combination of hypovolemic (intravascular fluid loss because of capillary 
leak) and cardiogenic shock (because of myocardial depression by circulating inflammatory 
mediators) in association with infection.

questions.question:
Question 14: A 3-year-old baby was brought by his parents to the ER. The parents complained that the 
child had been lethargic for a few hours and unresponsive for the past 30 mins. They give a 
history of 4-5 episodes of vomiting in the past one day. On examination, the baby had 
tachycardia, tachypnea, and very slow capillary refill time. The pediatrician asks you to 
initiate IV fluid therapy with a 24G IV cannula. Which colour IV cannula would you use?
questions.explanation: The color of the 24 G cannula is yellow. 24 G cannula is usually used for paediatric age group.

questions.question: Question 15: All of the following are causes of normal anion gap metabolic acidosis, except

options.c: Acidosis due to intestinal bacterial overgrowth

questions.explanation:
Acidosis due to intestinal bacterial overgrowth causes high anion gap metabolic acidosis because 
of excessive bacterial metabolism of glucose into lactic acid. Anion gap Normally, in the serum, the total number of cations is equal to the total number of anions. 
But, few of the anions (lactate, phosphate, and sulphate) cannot be measured and this is called an 
anion gap. Anion gap = [Na+] ([Cl-]+[HCO3-]) Metabolic acidosis Metabolic acidosis is of two types: (1) Normal anion gap metabolic acidosis (NAGMA) • Diarrhea (Loss of bicarbonate is compensated by chloride reabsorption) • Renal tubular acidosis • Urinary tract diversions (reabsorption of ammonium and hydrogen by the bowel) (2) High anion-gap metabolic acidosis (HAGMA) • Lactic acidosis (hypoxia, malignancy) • Ketoacidosis (diabetic, starvation) • Poisoning (ethylene glycol, methanol, salicylate) 178 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 16: Rani, a 6-year-old girl, who is known to have thalassemia, presented to the emergency with 
weakness, chest pain, and palpitations. There is a history of recent blood transfusion. The 
ECG of the child shows tall and peaked T-waves and flat P-waves as shown below. What could 
be the cause? 171 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The given electrocardiograph (ECG) characteristics show tall and peaked T-waves, flat P waves 
and since the girl has a recent history of massive blood transfusion, the most likely diagnosis 
is hyperkalemia. Hyperkalemia may be due to blood transfusion (stored blood has increased potassium 
concentration, due to the failure of the Na+-K+ ATPase pump). Causes of Hyperkalemia: • Spurious laboratory value • Sampling error • Thrombocytosis • Leucocytosis • Increased intake • Oral or intravenous • Blood transfusions • Transcellular shifts • Acidosis • Tumor lysis syndrome • Hemolysis • Decreased excretion • Renal failure • Hyporeninemic hypoaldosteronism 179 
Sold by @itachibot • Drugs • ACE inhibitors • ARB (angiotensin receptor blockers) • Potassium-sparing diuretics ECG Changes of Hyperkalemia • Tall and peaked T waves • Increased PR interval • Flattening of the P wave • ST-segment depression • Widening of the QRS complex Note: Tall T waves are also seen in myocardial ischemia. Option A: • There will be history of fever and ECG shows diffuse ST elevation. Option B: • Patient presents with features of cardiac failure and ECG shows ventricular arrhythmias. Option C: • Pulmonary hypertension is a known complication of hemolytic diseases (free Hb, angiotrophic 
factors causing vasoconstriction) and ECG shows right ventricular hypertrophy (RVH). 180 
Sold by @itachibot Mendelian and Non-Mendelian Disorders
